issues.title: Using H3_DATAGRAM_ERROR is weird
issues.author: LPardue
issues.body:
> Endpoints that abort the request stream due to an unexpected or malformed WRAP_UP capsule received over HTTP/3 SHOULD use the H3_DATAGRAM_ERROR error code when aborting the stream.

I realize we defined that error code but it especially sticks out if we consider WRAP_UP could be used for a capsule protocol stream that doesn't even use datagrams. Ok ok, https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9297#section-5.2 says 

> Description: Datagram or Capsule Protocol parse error

But I can see people getting quite confused by this name, if for example we had a [connect-tcp stream](https://httpwg.org/http-extensions/draft-ietf-httpbis-connect-tcp.html#name-use-of-the-capsule-protocol) that observed two WRAP_UPS and wanted to reset

I think the answer is probably to define generic [H2_|H3]_CAPSULE_ERROR in https://LPardue.github.io/draft-pardue-capsule-ext-guidance/draft-pardue-capsule-ext-guidance.html. So jsut using this issue to highlight something that sticks out that might get addressed elsewhere.

comments.author: DavidSchinazi
comments.body:
Yeah it's kinda. I'll update WRAP_UP to match what we did for [connect-ip](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9484#section-4.7.2-8):

> If any of the capsule fields are malformed upon reception, the receiver of the capsule MUST follow the error-handling procedure defined in [Section 3.3](https://rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9297#section-3.3) of [[HTTP-DGRAM](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9484#RFC9297)].

Totally agree that we should fix this in draft-pardue-capsule-ext-guidance. I filed https://github.com/LPardue/draft-pardue-capsule-ext-guidance/issues/1

pulls.title: Expand the introduction to talk about a wider range of problems
pulls.author: LPardue
pulls.body:
We discussed on the list and elsewhere a borader set of cases where
something like WRAP_UP could be useful. The specifics are still in flux.
The were some thoughts on other capsule types we could define, or we may
decide to punt on that work entirely.

However, I thought it might be useful to put into prose (my recollection)
of the discussion of the problem space.

I left it as a "read between the lines" thing, but I have use cases where
wrapping HTTP streams in a capsule protocol can help address operational
issues within a system. I'm hoping moving away from CONNECT proxy specific
language can help folks realise there's other applicability.

This is wall of text. We might decide that cherry-picking pieces out
is the best thing for now.
